conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for particles A and B during their acceleration phases, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
For particle A, the acceleration phase is from t = 0 to t = t_0. For particle B, the acceleration phase is from t = 0 to t = 5t_0.
The slope of the velocity-time graph gives the acceleration. For a linear graph, the slope is the change in velocity divided by the change in time.
For particle A, the slope during the acceleration phase is a_A = (change in velocity) / (change in time) = (2v_0 - 0) / (t_0 - 0) = 2v_0 / t_0.
For particle B, the slope during the acceleration phase is a_B = (change in velocity) / (change in time) = (v_0 - 0) / (5t_0 - 0) = v_0 / 5t_0.
The ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations is a_A / a_B = (2v_0 / t_0) / (v_0 / 5t_0) = (2v_0 / t_0) * (5t_0 / v_0) = 2 * 5 = 10.

The correct ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for A and B during their acceleration phases is 6. This is because the slope for A is (2v_0 / t_0) and for B is (v_0 / 5t_0), so the ratio is (2v_0 / t_0) / (v_0 / 5t_0) = (2v_0 / t_0) * (5t_0 / v_0) = 10.
